Posts.Title: 4 weeks post Chemo... what is normal? Camillia ruthbru

Posts.Content: Camillia wrote: I was wondering how everyone else felt. I worry about every little ache and wonder what is "normal" after chemo. How long after your last chemo did you hurt? I had 4 rounds of chemo with Neulasta after each one. I tolerated the whole thing quite well, thankfully. I am a little tired, but that's really not my complain. What I worry about is the bone pain that's always in the same areas (lefy upper leg and left side in what seems to be the stomach area). Anyone else experience some pain that is lasting after chemo? Mon onc said not to worry on my last visit, a week after last chemo, that it would go away. I just dont like the fact that it's in a specific area. It's not constant pain, more like a dull pain that feels almost like a bruise (the leg hurts more but it comes and goes). I hate that my mind goes to dark places when I think about it Dx 6/2012, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/6 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Getting a cold during chemo Camillia BikerLee

Posts.Content: Camillia wrote: Ok, so I had my second TC chemo last Thursday, with a neulasta shot. First time I did great, my wb count came back great and this time around I am going in on Friday to get blood drawn for a regular follow up.  I have little kids that go to school every day and we talked about washing handsand all but the inevitable has happened; one of them- bless his heart he tries so hard to wash his hands all the time!- brought a cold home :-( Only been 2 days and I already have it. My question is, how concern should I be? Anyone have experience with this? How likely is it to cause big trouble? Should my body fight this relatively easily? So far, all I have is a runny and congested nose. Can one have a cold during chemo and not land in thehospital or seriously ill? Thanks for sharing... I'm a little worried here :-( Dx 6/2012, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/6 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2013 07:35PM Camillia wrote: The breast MRI was very easy for me; it took a little while, but no headache or discomfort before, during or after. I had 2 tumors in my breast; they were both seen on the mammogram and us. The MRI did show they were multifocal but it didn't mean a worse scenario for me; my bs was already thinking a MX was better for me so it only made that decision that much easier.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed this morning... dawnettejh christina0001

Posts.Content: May 22, 2014 10:32PM Camillia wrote: I am so sorry that you are having to go through this. It does get better. It takes time and it will be a journey, but it will get better. I was diagnosed at 37, I have 3 young children so I can relate to how you feel. Almost 2 years later, I am stronger and healthy. Someone once told me that I would get to a new better place, a "new normal" and it did happen. I feel good again and I no longer live in constant fear. You will have lows and highs... at fist the lows will take most of the room and slowly, the highs will last longer until one day you suddenly realize that you have not thought about cancer or fear in days :-) Sending you a hug.
Posts.Title: Scared and feeling alone Nimm Camillia

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2013 07:33PM - edited Jan 22, 2013 11:22PM by Camillia I had 2 tumors at diagnosis, in 2 different quadrants. Both had small satellites around them. My surgeon highly recommended mastectomy, she said in a case like mine, it was the best way to make sure that we got everything out. She also said that lumpectomy was an option but that my breast would be very difform after surgery from having that much tissue taken out (I am a b cup). I opted for mastectomy. Best of luck.

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2013 01:32PM Camillia wrote: I am so sorry, Cuetang, that you have to find yourself here. I remember all too well feeling overwhelemd and the nights I spend tossing and waking up all the time. If that can help you at all, it has been 6 months since my surgery (so 7 months since diagnosis and coming up on 3 months since last chemo) and I am doing great. I remember wondering how would life ever go back to normal, worrying about my 3 young kids, my mind going to dark places, trying to figure out how this could have happened, analyzing every little detail about my life, nutrition, medication, past x-rays, fertility drugs, contraceptive pill, alocohol consumption, etc. How could this happen to me, I am young, healthy, active, had recently switched to a vegetatian diet?! You have just been traumatised. What you are feeling is normal and I promise that it will pass. Let the eomotions come to you, allow yourself to feel what ever it is that you are feeling. If you feel crapy, so be it. If you're worried, that's ok too. Scared... confused... just let it all come to you. Some of the best things I have done were being part of a groupd of woman at the hospital that met once a week, we all had breat cancer and just talked. The hospital also offered a free consultations service and talking with the person one on one there has really helped me deal with the emotions. The more steps I took, the more secure I felt. Surgery & treatment choice and end of treatments were big mile stones for me. Life has certainly changed and "normal" is not the same as it was, but I can honestly say that I feel stronger now. You will be amazed at the wonderful people in your life. Things will settle down. On day at a time, this too shall pass. Right now, you're still in the middle of it. The more time passes, the better you will be. Give it time.

But I didn't make a big deal of it, one day at a time. I will go and give it another try this morning ;-)

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2013 11:53PM Camillia wrote: I had a short pixie cut done about a month before starting chemo so that my kids would get used to it instead of going from long to bald within a couple of weeks. 9 days after my first chemo, my hair started falling out quite easily so I had my kids give me a short buzz cut- around 3/4". A couple of days after that, I went into the shower and ALL of my hair fell out at once. It was a very bad experience for me, I remember crying and freaking out about all the hair everywhere. If I would have known that it would fall that easily in the shower and all at once, I would have shaved it to a 1/4 inch the day my kids gave me a buzz cut. As for hats and scarfs, I personally tried quite a few things. It made me feel better to have the options of playing with scarfs, hats and all. I was lucky, it was winter. Good luck.
Posts.Title: How fast did your hair fall out? JennH8 JennH8

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2012 09:28PM Camillia wrote: WOW! Thanks for all the info, what a great ressource! I am writting down questions for for DR as I read each reply. It seems as though there is never a definitive answer with this journey we are on. It's never black or white. We live in a small town and the option to get second opinions that could vary greatly isn't really here. I trust my dr's and my onco is very kind and has a very human approach, but I dont like that she seems to want to stick to the book so closely. She doesn't really want to talk about me not getting  a port or choosing between such and such drugs. It has me wondering "is it because it trully is the best option for my health or is it because that's standard procedure and (yes, I do wonder) also more $ for the hospital". She did mention that it could ruin my veins and I do understand that. But how big is the risk? I respect everyone's choice because in the end it really comes down to what you can live with as an individual. I personnaly feel that if I need a scar to remind me of what I survived, I can lift my shirt up and see the scar that goes from the middle of my chest all the way to my armpit, LOL! (had a full mastectomy). My dear friend on the other end does say that she is proud of her scars. If I can avoid an extra procedure, I think I would. Reading all of your posts gives me the strenght to go back and ask more questions without feeling like I am a pain in the butt. Thanks ladies :-)

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2013 07:58PM - edited Jan 26, 2013 07:59PM by Camillia In my case too they had found one lump at first and then a second U/s showed a second lump. Mri showed satellites around those too lumps... it just kept getting worse with every test they did. Then a phone call with the positive results from the 1st biopsy and a few days later, the secons one was positive too. My tumors were 1.9 and 1.2mm. Bigger than Joan's. After all that negative stuff, the good news came after mastectomy that my nodes were negative. So I was stage 1. I had to decide if I was going to do chemo or not. I too had been told that I might not need it at all but efter a few dr's opinions, I decided to go for 4 rounds (I had some LVI... another way cancer could have spread). Chemo was no fun, but it was certainly doable and not at all as bad as I expected it to be. I am now on Tamoxifen... AND CANCER FREE My chances of recurences are very low (under 10%). 3 months past last treatment and feeling great (I just wish I had more hair, haha!) I know it is hard right now, but it will get easier. One step at a time. It will make both of you stronger.
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed now MRI finds a 2nd Lump jfelice Camillia

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2013 08:11PM Camillia wrote: Any news on Joan's 2nd biopsy today? Satellites are small cancerous tumors found around the main tumor. Mine were seen on a breast MRI but not on u/s. My tumors were in fact bigger than Joan's (1.9cm/19mm and 1.2cm/12mm). The size of your tumor, as I am sure you know, is one of the factors that determines what stage your cancer is. The fact that I had 2 tumors did not change my statistics. The dr's looked at my bigger tumor and that's how they staged me. If both of Joan's tumor (and maybe the second one wont even be cancerous) are under 1cm/10mm that is really good news. I think survival rates are very close to 100% at that stage. Good luck with surgery on Thursday. Is Joan going to have a lumpectomy or mastectomy? I will be thinking of you and look forward to hearing how well everything went
